documents.title: that 's it for today !
text: thanks to everyone who posted questions and to romola for her fantastic answers .
until next time !
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 2:00pm thanks so much for your questions - it was great chatting to you .
tickets are still available for the young vic 's measure for measure , which will involve wacky sets and lots of very emotional acting .
akersley asks : loved that comment at the baftas when you presented an award just after having a child !
did you plan to say that or was it just an off the cuff thing ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:59pm no i planned to say it .
i said that i 'd had 27 stitches in my vagina , so i did n't think i 'd be laughing at anything very soon , when giving an award for comedy acting .
pagey asks : did you understand the criticisms levelled at inside i 'm dancing by disabled people for using non-disabled actors ?

guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:58pm i understood the criticisms , but i felt sad for the film , which was a geniune attempt to raise the issue of independent living and the problem that society has with disabled people , and their right to be independent , and live and work with freedom .

no film on this subject has been made subsequently , but other films using able-bodied actors such as the stephen hawking biopic have been made and did n't seem to suffer the same level of criticism .

perhaps disabled actors should have been cast in that film , but i still feel proud that it was a film on an important topic that raised important issues , and feel sad that it was n't promoted because of that controversy .
simbadiow asks : measure for measure is known as a problem play .
do you have any problems character wise playing one of shakespeare 's females in this very patriarchal play ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:56pm i do n't think it is a patriarchal play .
i think it 's a profoundly misunderstood play .
i think directors misread isabella as a character .
she 's a fiercely strong character .
i would say one of the strongest in shakespeare .

he 's given a woman a platform to express the truth that rape is not a bargaining tool , she absolutely has the moral imperative and at the end that opportunity to be the only true force for good in the play .
it 's the female hamlet or macbeth .
but has been misinterpreted by patriarchal readers .
james howells asks : you 're a wonderful actress .
leftfield question : how did you come to get involved with the chemical brothers on the videos for further ?
the visuals are a treat - are you a fan ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:54pm i did n't know very much about `` dance music '' , what the kids are into is always a bit of a surprise to me .
i just got the request from my agent , and i thought it would be interesting .
to be honest they shot it in the underwater tank in pinewood , and the day involved swimming in it - i 'm a passionate swimmer , and i liked the idea of getting in a 40ft deep tank .
jocksstrap asks : do you think that jeremy corbyn looks like obi wan kanobe from the original star wars ?
and do you fancy him ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:53pm i have seen the original star wars but not for a very long time , and am largely totally disinterested in star wars as a franchise .
i do n't fancy jeremy corbyn , but then i 've nothing to suggest he would fancy me either .
derorabrown asks : like you , i trained with the national youth theatre , but went to university rather than drama school .
tentatively , now i 've graduated , i am attempting to continue acting .
i know it is probably a while back for you , but , once you were auditioning for film or theatre , is there any advice you were given/things you learned yourself that you 've heeded ?
your opinion is particularly interesting , because you come across so refreshingly thoughtful but you already know that .
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:52pm i 'm so glad you noticed that !
remember you 're auditioning them .
acting is a collaboration with the director , and it 's only a worthwhile job if the director respects you completely as an equal .
go into every audition knowing that you 're an equal and expect to be treated as such .
and have fun collaborating .
moybridge asks : i really enjoyed your performance in francois ozon 's angel .
i though it was very smartly played and tonally quite a tricky thing to pull off .
do you have a preference for acting styles ?
do certain styles come more naturally to you or is it the nature of the job that you just shift to whatever production your in ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:50pm i 'm never consciously aware of style when i 'm acting .
i 'm aware of tone , but that i think very much is largely the director 's preserve , especially on film , so they have to tell you what tone they 're looking for .

i have to say that film is probably my most proud moment , i loved the film and i loved being in it - it was such an intelligent film about creativity and performance , and it was a delight to work with such a deeply intelligent and playful filmmaker .
anaveragejoe asks : after looking at your wiki ' page , it would seem to suggest that you may be a hungary italian so my , possibly most obvious question , is , have you a healthy appetite ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:48pm my dad 's family were originally from hungary , but i do n't have any italian blood , just the name .

ladynow asks : i loved your masha in filter 's three sisters five years ago ; how did you find the experience of doing a more experimental interpretation of chekhov , after the more traditional seagull ( also a wonderful performance ! ) ?
should we be more flexible in our approach to producing classic texts ?

guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:47pm i think there 's an emphasis today on design , so it looks like we have a very flexible approach because we do wacky things with design , but actually performance style is actually very unified in this country .

and what i really liked about working with filter was they were trying to inject a real sense of realism into the performances , which made the performances quite muted , which i thought was interesting because english actors are expected to be very emotional on stage a lot of the time .
i think basically classic plays become classics because you can do them in lots of different ways , and that they should always be done differently .
but i do n't think having a wacky set or different costumes necessarily means that you 're reinventing the play .

documents.title: book , film and music recommendations from romola
text: jason davis says : i love your works , thank you for creating such compelling characters and artfully exploring diverse themes so authentically .

you are truly inspiring and i so look forward to seeing your incredible gravitas/also lightness in equal measure when you are on the screen i 'm wondering if you could recommend a book or movie ( or a song ) you love these days ?

guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:44pm i read an amazing book this year that i recommend very highly , called we are all completely beside ourselves by karen joy fowler , which i thought was one of the best novels i 've read ever .
it just destroyed me .
i felt like she 's a writer that 's writing at the absolute top of her game , it was amazingly structured .
and the emotional weight of the story was being crushed by a rock , it flattened you as the story went on .
i ca n't say too much without revealing a reveal that happens very early on movie , i saw a great movie confusingly called house of cards , but in no way related to the series .
it had kathleen turner and tommy lee jones in it , and it 's about a woman who thinks her child has autism - it was given to me by someone who read my script and said i should see it .
if you want a really fantastic unusual drama - the kind we depressingly do n't make very much any more - i really recommend it .
i 'm not very good with the hit parade !
this is embarassing i basically only listen to contemporary composition like john taverner and john adams when i 'm working and katy perry when i 'm cooking .
and that 's it , basically .
katelyn o asks : i absolutely loved your performance as bel in the hour and i really wish it had returned for a third series !
so i was wondering what you think would 've happened in a 3rd series and also what was it like working with peter capaldi ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:40pm no-one wishes it would return for a third series more than me !
people are always saying it 's such a shame and i 'm like : yeah .
the third series would have been in the 60s , so it would have gone into the moon landings , been much more cold war , and there was some talk of bel possibly getting married .
it was delightful working with peter - he is very experienced .

sometimes when you work with actors who have done so much stuff , you can feel them waiting for you to get the scene right - they 're really supporting and encouraging , but they 're having to go through all your terrible takes .
he 's very funny , a really nice man .
jasonaparkes asks : have you been offered more comedy roles after delivering those killer lines at the baftas in 2013 ?
it was as funny as something in how to be a woman by caitlin moran guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:38pm no i have n't !
i think because i 'm banging on about feminism in a really angry way , no-one offers me comedy

documents.title: `` i think there should be quotas . if you 're fielding primetime television with 80 % of the parts being white men , you should probably rethink that ''
text: andrew jamieson asks : your performance in the hour was an iconic piece of breathless british television .
do you feel there are enough great roles around for actresses on television and screen in both hollywood and around the world ?
does something need to change in your opinion ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:37pm i think there should be quotas .
i think if you 're fielding primetime television with 70 % and 80 % of the parts being white men , you should probably rethink that .
there 's a lot of tokenism in film and television , with a poster with three white guys , one black guy , and a woman , and that 's equality , and it 's not equality .

documents.title: `` the pornification of television has had a massive effect on actresses ''
text: baharkoru asks : you have performed at many stages ; tv , cinema and theater .
which one is your favorite ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:36pm i do n't have a favourite .
i think the ideal for me would be for me to do a little bit of all .
but actually , all i really care about is playing interesting parts .
i think i can get quite bored at work if i do n't have something to get my teeth into , and that 's really my only priority or concern .
there just are n't enough parts for women across the board in film and television , of any kind .
if you 've got 30 % of speaking roles for women , if you say 20 % of those are shit , then you 've got 10 % of good parts - there 's an awful lot of competition for those roles .
because of the emphasis we put on creative women becoming actors as opposed to other creative occupations .
the emphasis for young girls who feel a creative spark is : do n't you want to be an actress ?
a man can sit down and think : maybe i want to be an architect , or a set designer it means there are a lot of actresses vying for a few parts .
film and television has also become very misogynistic in the last fifteen years so the problem has got worse .
i think that the blossoming of nudity as entertainment has much more affected women that men , and there are a lot of shows that have tit quotas .
so the pornification of television has had a massive effect on actresses .
i have a lot of friends who are told if you do n't get your tits out , we 'll get the supporting artists to do it , but someone has to .
i do n't think audiences understand what a difficult position it is putting women who are n't trained to be strippers into turning their bodies to their occupation in that way .
no one has ever told me to get my top off , but i know it happens .
i 'm at the stage where i would n't go in on a job if i thought that was going to happen .
and you know , it often the writer 's attitude .

it 's not seen as a morally unforgivable thing for a male character to have sex with a prostitute , it 's seen as an extension of a reckless , sexy antihero , and i do n't think that was the case 10 or 15 years ago on television .
i 'm hoping that what will happen is it will get a lot worse and people will think oh god , is this what we want ?
probably not though .
david simmons asks : really looking forward to seeing you in measure for measure , romola .
any chance of indian ink being performed on the london stage ?
( with you in it , of course ! )
: o ) guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:29pm no !
badarivishal kinhal asks : how do you prepare as an actor for a role ?
are there any specific routines that you follow irrespective of the role you are going to essay ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:29pm no .
i do n't really prepare very much .
i suppose i do as much as the director wants .
for this part , because joe and i have been talking about it since january , we did quite a lot of research for her and i went and stayed in a convent and read a lot of books about nuns .
and all my friends got very bored about me talking about nuns .

i think it 's a useful thing to remember in our secular bubble of the chatterati that most people in the world live with profound and devout faith - i do n't think you can go into this play without respect for people with faith .
it was a good reminder of a life where you wrestle with the big questions , which a life of faith requires .
on the night , i do a warm up i guess .
but actually i think if this is an actor asking this question , i think character work is a very two headed monster .
it gives you ideas , but it leads you away from the text .
i 'm of the opinion really that you 're best advised to follow the text as close as possible .
if you stray away from the page , you can get a bit lost .
i think also shakespeare tells you everything you need to know .
it 's useful , but it has to be treated with caution .
id8763929 asks : given a choice of part in measure for measure , which would you prefer to play isabella or angelo ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:25pm angelo , of course !
i went for angelo , i did n't get it .
but i 'm always giving paul lots of notes about how to play him .
è²³e¸ä¾¯ asks : how does being a mother influence or inspire your career ?
can you reveal some clues about the upcoming features you 're involved in , like churchill 's secret ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:25pm churchill 's secret is a one-off 90 minute tv drama , about winston churchill , surprise surprise .
and churchill 's secret is that he was a woman !

no , he had a stroke in 1952 and there 's some historical evidence that he had brain damage after that stroke , so even though he went on to win the election and serve another term , he was seriously affected by the stroke .
it focuses on his recovery from that stroke , and his deep need for power - his refusal to let power go .
steamrollering his wife clementine 's desire for him to retire .
the part i play , his nurse , is a sort of subplot , where she encourages him to carry on working because she feels vocation is the only real reason people have to live .
aurora esterlia asks : i really liked you in as you like it ( 2006 ) , i was 15 years old and since then you are one of my favourite actress that i always want to see on movies .
the hour was a blessing for me because it 's a tv series and i can see you in every episode .
who 's your favourite actress all of whose movies you have been watching since childhood/your teenage years ?
: ) guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:22pm maybe winona ryder ?
i 've always been a really big fan .
she 's a genius actress , who was maybe not empowered by the industry maybe that 's a very presumptuous thing to say !
she 's just supremely vulnerable and intelligent ; i 've always been very moved by her , even when i was a teenager .
my favourite actress when i was a teenager was probably sandra bullock .

i remember watching speed when i was 14 , and i thought she was really funny and clever , and they do n't write parts like that so much any more , where she does n't have to get her t-shirt off at any stage .
she drives the plot forward and she 's a very strong presence on screen .
olivia giorgia warren says : romola , you 're wonderful .
i am a young ambassador at the young vic and in training as an actor musician at rose bruford college .
i wonder , why do you think theatre is relevant today and what do you get from being in or seeing a marvellous show ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:19pm i think theatre is relevant , mainly because it 's paying me .
what do i get from it ?
i do n't know if i 've ever been in a marvellous show , that 's very subjective !
i love acting on stage , because i feel it 's a very confronting way to tell a story- there 's no escape like there is in cinema .

cinema can be a very constructed medium where the director gets to choose what to show and how to show it ; theatre is much more democratic , it 's an open exchange of ideas between the audience and actors , and everyone should feel truly challenge .
it should feel like a creative back and forth ; at its best you should n't feel whether you 're giving a good performance .
instead : are the audience hearing the story as clearly as they can ?
when the audience hears the playwright speaking to them , you 've done a good job .
i like the democracy of theatre .
seeing a great play is the same - it 's as much of a thrill as being in one that works .
it should make you feel things .
a question from kats on twitter : what has been your most challenging/demanding role ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:16pm challenging is not the same as demanding i do n't think .
in terms of challenging roles i 've played , i 've been super lucky - i 've played a lot that i 've loved .
i loved playing sugar in crimson petal and the white , and it was a challenge because i desperately was afraid of not doing it right , because i love the source material so much .
but i was really supported by the director .
i loved playing becky in the village bike , that was a challenge because i feel it is a very important play , and again i was very concerned about being the weak link and not serving the play well .

i think in terms of demanding roles , i actually had a very difficult time on indian ink , tom stoppard 's play that i did last year - i think sometimes you try and try and just do not understand the character 's dilemma , and the director is never able to help you understand enough .
and those experiences you have to chalk up as learning experiences , although the audience has to sit through your failed creative endeavour !
it was just me , really , and sometimes that does n't translate out front - people said they had a good night , but i wanted to walk home and shower because i felt so fucking awful .

and sometimes i think i 've knocked it out of the park , and people are in the bar saying jeez , when are we going to break it to her that it 's not working the most demanding experiences i 've had have been disagreeing with actors over the ownership of the story , and its message , and if you feel passionately about gender politics that 's a really difficult thing to bring into a creative endeavour as they 're dominated by male concerns .
the production sees the audience as exclusively male , and you 're expected to play to a male audience .
i imagine that will continue to be a complete fucking nightmare for the rest of my life .
it 's pretty common - it 's not every job , but there 's jobs i ca n't even go in on , because i can not hang my flag on this , you know ?
it 's hard to criticise an industry though , that 's reflecting what viewers think of as acceptable .

people think supporting actors paid poorly to be naked on television , or rape de as entertainment without a voice for the victim , is acceptable , so studios and production companies do n't limit that because audiences accept it .
lloydhutchinson asks : has joe hill gibbons got you into queens of the stone age yet ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:08pm he has n't mentioned them i 'll ask him when i go back this afternoon .
maybe i should be afraid to ask him !
were you bored to tears by joe talking about queens of the stone age ?

documents.title: `` having a child is the most incredible artistic gift ''
text: john fusco asks : above all , i love how your approach & how passionate you are on any number of things .
what can you share with us regarding your own upcoming feature film ?
pretty confidant you 're there , back in the director 's chair too !

: - ) guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:07pm i 'm trying to attach a producer to my feature , which is a sort of supernatural horror set in the 1950s about motherhood and creativity .
i 'm hoping to direct it sometime next year .
i 've written it too .
it 's about a woman who 's a successful novelist , who 's about to write her second novel , when she gets pregnant with her first child - that child turns out to have autism .
in the early days of autism research , it was believed to be caused by a maternal distance , and because of the diagnosis , is forced to give up her career .
having a child is the most incredible artistic gift because it deepens and widens and enhances your understanding of the human condition - it did for me anyway .
a lot of things i had thought were important in art were quite trivial actually - i was very caught up with form , and i realised that story was king .
i was n't so afraid of emotion afterwards .
and i was n't afraid of being laughed at .
the emotional cost of being away from your child to do anything artistic - and the financial cost of paying a babysitter !
- and do something so self-indulgent as `` make art '' i think made me braver .
and also thematically was inspiring to me .
that dilemma : is it important to be away from your child ?
how important ?
it was a source of inspiration .

documents.title: shakesperare ? `` i think he 's patchy , but the good stuff is really good ''
text: faceyface asks : william shakespeare is he any good , really ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:03pm i think he 's patchy , but the good stuff is really good .
mick noya asks : i became a huge fan of the hour ( hard not to ) .
i thought your acting in it , as well as that of your fellow actors , was outstanding .
given the climate of great series ( canceled and otherwise ) making a return ( netflix , amazon , etc ) , is there any possibility of the hour coming back at some point ?
would you be interesting in returning to the show if possible ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:02pm i would do the hour if they brought it back for sure - but it has been quite a long gap now .
i think it could be brought back on netflix and amazon but i have n't heard any rumour of that happening .
the trouble is that abi morgan is one of the most in-demand writers in the world , so i do n't know if they could get her back .

documents.title: `` have i ever read a criticism of me that i thought was constructive ? no ''
text: clareyesno asks : was it difficult bouncing back from dirty dancing 2 being a flop ?
do actors freak out when something does n't perform well , or is it just oh well , onto the next thing ?
guardian contributor romolagarai 15 september 2015 1:00pm well , i think i ca n't speak for all actors obviously , so some maybe do freak out when something does n't perform well .
i 've never been interested in how things perform financially .
i think it 's a producer 's job to worry about that .
in terms of critically it being a flop , i have to say it did n't really bother me .

i think what bothered me was how i as an individual feel about the story i 'm telling - if i feel it 's a good story with a message promoting something i believe in , then that is more important to me than anything else .

i think with critics , i 've seen so many films that i loathed that are critically lauded and so many films that i adore that never made any impact critically - i 'm not sure how much i value criticism myself .

which is n't to say it does n't have a value in opening up a debate , but i do n't always feel that criticism is doing what i think it should do which is defend the new and the brave and award noble artistic endeavour rather than propping up establishment ideas .
have i ever read a criticism of me that i thought was constructive ?
no .
i usually find reviews are very polarised , so if you invest in the positive ones you have to invest in the negative ones , and that 's impossible .
if you give a performance that 's universally adored , and you read the reviews , you can lose the performance - you become very self-aware .
i 've seen actors give performances that i 've loved be destroyed by reviews , and that 's sad .
all reviews are is taste , which does n't help you as an actor .
which is n't to say you 're not devastated at a bad review ; i 've cried , all that .

documents.title: post your questions for romola garai
text: the popular image of romola garai is of an english rose in a costume drama .
on screen there have been corset-rippers like the prostitute sugar in the crimson petal and the white and pioneering career women such as bel rowley , her 1950s tv producer in the hour .
in new film suffragette she will star alongside carey mulligan and meryl streep .

but her politics are firmly rooted in the present day , highlighting the plight of palestinian refugees in the film no man 's land , and telling the evening standard recently : parenthood is on the slag heap of priorities to our government , and it 's just madness because that 's how you grow your citizens .
an accomplished stage actor , she 's played cordelia to ian mckellen 's king lear and nina in the seagull for the rsc .

ahead of her latest role as isabella , in the young vic 's new production of measure for measure , she 's joining us to answer your questions in a live webchat from 1pm bst onwards on tuesday 15 september .
post them in the comments below , and she 'll answer as many as possible .
